articles.headline: Panel Seeks Social Security Cuts and Higher Taxes
articles.snippet: A politically provocative and economically ambitious plan to reduce the debt is a challenge to both parties.
articles.abstract: A politically provocative and economically ambitious plan to reduce the debt is a challenge to both parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The chairmen of President Obama’s bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt outlined a politically provocative and economically ambitious package of spending cuts and tax increases on Wednesday, igniting a debate that is likely to grip the country for years.

articles.headline: In-Flight Fire Endangers Delivery Date for Boeing 787
articles.snippet: Test flights for the 787 Dreamliner were halted a day after an onboard fire forced an emergency landing.
articles.abstract: Test flights for the 787 Dreamliner were halted a day after an onboard fire forced an emergency landing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing halted test flights on Wednesday of its 787 Dreamliner, a day after an onboard fire forced an emergency landing, reinforcing expectations that the long-awaited plane faced more delays.

articles.headline: Countries See Hazards in Free Flow of Capital
articles.snippet: Foreign capital in emerging markets has played a crucial role in development, but some are questioning its benefits.
articles.abstract: Foreign capital in emerging markets has played a crucial role in development, but some are questioning its benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  In China and Taiwan, regulators are imposing fresh restrictions on stock market investments by foreigners. In Brazil, officials have twice raised taxes on foreign investors. Even in South Korea, host to this week’s Group of 20 meeting, pressure is building on the government to take similar steps.

articles.headline: It’s a Tablet. It’s Gorgeous. It’s Costly.
articles.snippet: Samsung presents the Galaxy Tab, a new Android tablet with many features and a light touch. But it’ll cost you.
articles.abstract: Samsung presents the Galaxy Tab, a new Android tablet with many features and a light touch. But it’ll cost you.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every time there’s some new hot, heavily hyped gadget from Apple, it takes only a few months for the copycats to crop up. IPod? Zune! IPhone? Android!

articles.headline: Drug Suits Raise Questions for Doctors, and Juries
articles.snippet: As recent lawsuits suggest a long-term risk, doctors and drug makers are debating the use of osteoporosis drugs.
articles.abstract: As recent lawsuits suggest a long-term risk, doctors and drug makers are debating the use of osteoporosis drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judith Graves, a 67-year-old retired investigator for the United States Army, developed a rare medical condition called jawbone death after taking Fosamax, a drug used by millions of American women with thinning bones.

articles.headline: The Special Pain of a Slow Disaster
articles.snippet: Donors often use the number of deaths as a barometer for sending rapid aid to scenes of disasters, relief officials say.
articles.abstract: Donors often use the number of deaths as a barometer for sending rapid aid to scenes of disasters, relief officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE water came slowly, masking its power with sluggishness. But Farooq Tariq, a human rights activist long accustomed to helping hapless civilians through Pakistani disasters, knew it meant trouble.

articles.headline: Pledge to Give Away Fortunes Stirs Debate
articles.snippet: 40 of the wealthiest Americans pledge to give away at least half of their fortunes, about $600 billion.
articles.abstract: 40 of the wealthiest Americans pledge to give away at least half of their fortunes, about $600 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITHOUT a doubt, the biggest event in philanthropy this year was the Giving Pledge, a commitment by 40 of the wealthiest Americans to give away at least half of their fortunes, about $600 billion.

articles.headline: Life in Shadows for Mentally Ill in China
articles.snippet: Psychiatry has been revived in China, but mental health remains a medical backwater.
articles.abstract: Psychiatry has been revived in China, but mental health remains a medical backwater.
articles.lead_paragraph: XIZHEN, China  After five months in a rundown ward at the Hepu County Psychiatric Hospital, Yang Jiaqin no longer suffers terrifying hallucinations. Still, his wife dares not mention children, not even their own, for fear of unleashing the demons that possessed him one day last spring.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Says ‘Try This On’: Free Shipping
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest retailer will offer free shipping on its Web site, in a move that may change consumer expectations and threaten smaller retailers.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest retailer will offer free shipping on its Web site, in a move that may change consumer expectations and threaten smaller retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Wal-Mart has used its clout as the nation’s largest retailer to squeeze competitors with rock-bottom prices in its stores. Now it is trying to throw a holiday knockout punch online.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Obama’s Trade Strategy Runs Into Stiff Resistance
articles.snippet: The resistance to President Obama’s approach puts him at odds with his key allies and largest trading partners on fundamental issues of economic strategy.
articles.abstract: The resistance to President Obama’s approach puts him at odds with his key allies and largest trading partners on fundamental issues of economic strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Sewell Chan, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David E. Sanger.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David E. Sanger
